content.text: The student measures the depth of the water every minute
State the two pieces of equipment that she uses
On Fig. 1.2, label both axes with title and unit
The water rises up the jar at a constant rate
Draw a line on Fig. 1.2 to show the student's graph. Start the line from the time when the jar is empty
The student records her observations in a table. She then plots a graph using the axes shown in Fig. 1.2
A puddle of water forms on the ground. The average depth of the water is 2.5 mm
Determine the average depth of the water in m
A pipe drips water into an empty glass jar. A student takes measurements to find how fast the water is rising up the jar. Fig. 1.1 shows the arrangement
State the maximum speed of car A
Calculate the distance travelled by car B when accelerating
distance =   .........  m
Car C has a greater acceleration than car A, but it reaches a lower constant speed than car B
On Fig. 2.1, draw a line to show the movement of car C
Three racing cars, A, B and C, all accelerate steadily and then continue at a constant speed. Fig. 2.1 gives information about the movement of car A and car B at the start of the race
The mass of the tyre is \(15\mathrm{kg}\)
Calculate its weight
weight of tyre =   .........  N
Explain what is meant by the term moment
A child sits on the tyre. The weight of the child and tyre together is \(425\mathrm{N}\). Calculate the moment of this force about point P. Use information given in Fig. 3.1. Include the unit
A heavier child wants to sit on the tyre. Describe how the tyre position should be adjusted so that the moment is the same as in (b)(ii)
The weight of the tyre exerts a moment on the branch, about point P where the branch joins the tree
Fig. 3.1 shows a tyre hanging from the branch of a tree
The reservoirs store energy
State the terms used to describe the energy stored in the reservoirs
Describe how the energy stored in reservoir C becomes useful energy for the city at the hydroelectric station
Some of the stored energy is wasted. Explain what happens to this energy
Water from reservoirs A and B may flow into reservoir C. It is more efficient to fill reservoir C using water from reservoir B only
Suggest a reason for this
Fig. 4.1 shows a hydroelectric power system located in the mountains
Name the force that prevents a person from slipping
The stool has four legs. The area of each pad is \(3 \text{cm}^2\). The weight of the stool is \(75 \text{N}\). A student sits on the stool. The weight of the student is \(525 \text{N}\)
Calculate the pressure acting on the floor due to the student and the stool
pressure =   .........  \(\text{N/cm}^2\)
The legs of the stool are made of hollow metal tubes. Fig. 5.1 shows the bottom of a stool leg with and without a pad
Explain why a stool leg without a pad does more damage to the floor
A stool has a round non-slip pad fitted to the bottom of each leg
A laboratory floor has a surface that prevents people from slipping when the floor is wet
The metal changes from hot liquid to cool solid
Describe what happens to the arrangement, separation and motion of the atoms as the metal changes from hot liquid to cool solid
The workers cool their tools in water. They spill some water onto the floor but later the floor is dry
Explain what happens to the water. State the name of the process
explanation
process
Fig. 6.1 shows workers pouring liquid metal
Fig. 7.1 shows labels for parts of the electromagnetic spectrum, in order
Complete Fig. 7.1 by adding the two missing labels
State a use of infra-red radiation
Describe the harmful effect of microwaves on people
This question is about the electromagnetic spectrum
A nucleus of iodine-131 can be represented as
Determine the number of neutrons in a nucleus of iodine-131
number of neutrons   .........
\(\beta\) -particles and \(\gamma\) -rays are ionising radiations
Explain the meaning of ionising radiations
Fig. 8.1 shows a decay curve for iodine-131
Use information from Fig. 8.1 to determine the half-life of iodine-131. Show clearly how you used the graph
A different radioactive substance has a half-life of 120 hours
Calculate the time for it to decay to \(25\%\) of its original amount
time =   .........  hours
Iodine-131 is a radioactive isotope of iodine. Iodine-131 decays by the emission of a \(\beta\) -particle and a \(\gamma\) -ray
Explain why the man sees the flash of the explosion before he hears the bang
State the name given to this second bang
State how the second bang compares with the first bang in terms of its amplitude and speed
amplitude
speed
The man hears a second bang shortly after the first bang
The man stands \(170 \text{m}\) from the back rock face. The time between hearing the first bang and hearing the second bang is \(1.0 \text{s}\)
Use the information in Fig. 9.1 to determine the speed of sound in the quarry
speed of sound =   .........  m/s
Fig. 9.1 shows the position of a man working in a rock quarry. A single explosion is used to break part of one rock face
Explain why the small magnet is in the position shown in Fig. 10.1
The strong magnet is turned so that the opposite surface is now facing the small magnet. State and explain what happens, if anything
Describe a method for magnetising an iron pin using a permanent magnet
Explain how you would identify the poles of the magnet made in **(b)(i)**
Fig. 10.1 shows a demonstration with magnets
The strong magnet has a pole on its top surface and a pole on its bottom surface. The strong magnet is placed above a small magnet that is connected to a bench by a string
When the switch is closed, energy is transferred from the power supply. Explain what happens to this energy
He measures the current in the circuit. State the name of the component that he uses
The student measures the potential difference (p.d.) across the resistance wire. On Fig. 11.1, draw the correct symbol for the component he uses and show how he connects it
Fig. 11.2 shows the symbol for another component that the student adds to the circuit
State the name and function of this component
name
function
A student wants to determine the resistance of the wire. He adds components to the circuit shown in Fig. 11.1
Fig. 11.1 shows a power supply in series with a resistance wire and a switch
Describe how to demonstrate electromagnetic induction using a magnet, a coil of wire and a sensitive ammeter. You may include a diagram
State two factors that affect the size of an induced electromotive force (e.m.f.)
A student demonstrates electromagnetic induction
